results.title: VFX in Overwatch
results.brief_description: A look at the use of VFX in Blizzard Entertainment’s hit videogame Overwatch.

constellations_primary.name: Blizzard, Bowie and the Bonets
constellations_primary.description: Overwatch is the beginning of some surprising connections in this Constellation that explores videogame movies, cartoons, and music docos and shows.

results.description: In 2016 it seemed like Overwatch went from a game no one had heard of to a global pop culture phenomenon overnight. Yet it’s success was about more than just the mechanics of an advanced first-person shooter. Light on narrative inside the game, players worldwide became invested in the colourful cast thanks to animated short films released as bonus content. From tragic backstories to star-crossed romances, the game’s developer Blizzard Entertainment made sure their millions of users weren’t just invested in playable avatars, they were invested in characters.
description_for_label: In 2016 it seemed like Overwatch went from a game no one had heard of to a global pop culture phenomenon overnight. results.title: [Len Moncur Home Movie Collection]
results.brief_description:
The Len Moncur Home Movie Collection is a collection of amateur films made on 8mm film in the 1950s and 1960s. The collection includes a feature-length film of the 1956 Melbourne Olympics and four stop-motion animation titles: ‘The one-eyed monster’, ‘Storm at the 20th’, ‘One fine day’ and ‘It isn’t cricket’.

Len Moncur (1912–1997) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies and amimation films. With an interest in radio from a young age, he obtained his amateur transmitting licence in 1928, and served in the Air Force during WWII in radar service units. He purchased his first film camera in the USA in 1935, while on a trip visiting other radio and television experimenters, and began making home movies. He made an amaetur television set in 1950, which was shown at the All Models Exhibition, six years before the arrival of commerical television in Australia. In 1957, he joined the Melbourne 8mm Movie Club, where he regularly screened his home movies at film nights. Moncur’s 8mm stop-motion animation films won several amateur filmmaking awards in the 1960s.

This collection was donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s son Ken Moncur.

results.title: The Australian airman: 1939-1945
results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “War Experience”.
The men who served in the Royal Australian Air Force during the Second World War. At first it was a European war - over Germany, France, and Italy, but then the allies were driven back over North Africa. The Japanese aggression brought the men back to Australian shores and Pacific islands. Joining the Air Force with a spirit of adventure, the close of the war saw broken spirits and mental and physical suffering.

results.title: Blind grace
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: New York City — a huge, slow pulse of light steaming through daytime and night time. A study of the soul of the city, its radiance, its isolates and its irates — the special souls who are lost to the vision of the workaday world but scorched into the vision of Cohen’s video world. A world of blindness, grace and vision. A world made more sacred by noise — the special noise composed in response to the city’s scorching radiance, another kind of soul music.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film shows tugboats assisting ships into the piers at the Port of Melbourne and stars the “James Paterson” boat on which Kenneth is filming. The scenes in the reel show a lost world of shipping and the manual labour of port operations. The reel ends with the ‘James Paterson’ tugboat at the dock.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:30:00 title card ‘Pushing and Pulling’ and “starring James Paterson and Norman C. McBain”. Shortly after, we see a tugboat named ‘James Paterson’.

00:03:31:00 scenes of the workings of the tugboats in assisting ships in and out of port, stoking the engine fires, ships crews looking down from the great height of their vessels whilst the tugboats manoeuvre around them.

00:03:45:00 shots of boats and water and a large ship ‘Pipiriki’ leaving a pier and being towed by a tugboat from where Kenneth is filming, presumably on the ‘James Paterson’; we see shots of a harbour and ships and boats passing by as well as one the tugboat operator at the wheel.

00:04:07:00 we see the ship ‘Sanoma’ followed by men working lines on the tugboat alongside the ship.

00:07:55:00 ‘Melbourne Star’ ship, the ‘Wombat’ tugboat and ‘River Murumbidgee’.

00:09:15:00 we see a close up of rope work by the crew of the ‘Clan Macaulay’.

00:10:05:00 shows a great closeup shot of workers chatting on the tugboat.

00:11:50:00 a good shot of one of the dockside piers.

00:12:13:00 sequence from this point shows a ship hoisted into dry dock - Kenneth uses shots of the boat stop signal, a dry dock supply shop and the pier to emphasise the dry dock surrounds.

00:13:00:00 the scene changes to night time on the water followed by some passenger ships.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 21]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film captures the Rankine/Woottons holidaying at Gosford, NSW coast.

Selected highlights list:

(No title)
00:00:00:00 to 00:00:05:00 up to this point, footage of a train travelling over a causeway from the mainland which can be identified as the Gosford area on the NSW coast.

00:00:06:00 - 00:00:18:00 panoramic footage being filmed from a vantage point above and where we see the Wootton family relaxed and on holidays as illustrated by their innovative footwear for the time: rubber thongs which were first produced in Australia by Dunlop in 1959.

00:00:19:00 to 00:00:44:00 footage of the bays and the town (presumably Gosford).

00:00:45:00 a prolonged shot of the three Wootton children looking more grown up and confident in front of the camera.

00:01:02:00 the family gather around what is likely to be a metal map on a pedestal for tourists.

00:01:45:00 footage is taken from a higher vantage point again at and includes a shot of fellow tourists at 00:01:52:00.

00:01:55:00 ‘Ploddy the Dinosaur’ (erected 1963) at the Australian Reptile Museum and Sanctuary at Gosford where we see snakes, lizards and other species in enclosures.

00:02:42:00 the family feeding tame kangaroos and cockatoos.
.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 23]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film shows the Australian ‘outback’, focussing on Alice Springs. The start of the reel has shots of roads, erosion alongside the roads, surrounding countryside and distant views as well as Kenneth’s car on the road - an image he often used to indicate the film will capture a roadtrip.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:00:00 starts with a title card ‘Hello Alice’.

00:31:00:00 Map of Australia honing in on Alice Springs.

00:46:00:00 sign ‘Pichi Richi Pass - Caution - Creeks and Corners’.

00:1:09:0000:01:47:00 we sight a small steam train.

00:02:10:00 a rail bridge.

00:02:38:00 travellers arrive at the township of Quorn (South Australia)

00:03:01:00 the Quorn train station; long transport steam trains. sign for the township of Marree.

00:04:15:00 footage includes looking at the wheels and tracks, passengers awaiting trains, local Indigenous people, scenes of the outback taken from the train.

00:06:10:00 the traintrip reaches the township of Beresford and then the William Creek Hotel at 00:06:40:00 where we see passengers having fetched bottles of beer from the hotel sprinting back to the train.

00:06:50:00 a glimpse of (probably) brumbies and more scenes of locals and the surrounding countryside from travelling train.

00:09:27:00 we sight traindrivers or workers walking alongside the train, travel by a sheep station and through a very arid landscape.

00:10:20:00 the sign for Alice Springs comes into view. Kenneth starts a tour of the town with some police officers speaking to the camera and footage of families and their cars in one of the streets. Footage includes wandering around the wide dusty roads, people walking and on bicycles and then a look at the buildings - houses, a focus on an older building made (unusually of brick), eucalyptus trees and a flowering garden,

00:11:33:00 we see a sign for the ‘Australian Inland Mission Hostel for bush mothers and children’ on a building that Kenneth gives us several views of including a motorbike outside. This is followed by a view of a new and very modern looking building, surrounded by vegetable or market gardens and out front of which Mrs Rankine chats with acquaintances who point her up to a monument on a hill.

00:12:10:00 is a view from the monument, overlooking the town including views of its oval and what appears to be a prison.

00:13:19:00 view of eucalypts in the surrounding landscape.

00:13:40:00 we see a marker for ‘Flynn’s Grave’ which is a beautiful boulder perched on a stone pedestal.

00:14:04:00 a sign for ‘Standley Chasm’ appears and begins a sequence of dramatic and beautiful scenes of rocky outcrops, foliage and trees. Kenneth films some walkers among the rocks which shows the size and context of the environment.

00:15:31:00 we see two Indigenous horsemen followed by a sign for ‘Hermannsberg’ and some shots of the mission church building, some members of the community and a group of children smiling for the camera. The reel ends with some last looks at the landscape.
results.title_for_label: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 23]
results.description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film shows the Australian ‘outback’, focussing on Alice Springs. The start of the reel has shots of roads, erosion alongside the roads, surrounding countryside and distant views as well as Kenneth’s car on the road - an image he often used to indicate the film will capture a roadtrip.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:00:00 starts with a title card ‘Hello Alice’.

00:31:00:00 Map of Australia honing in on Alice Springs.

00:46:00:00 sign ‘Pichi Richi Pass - Caution - Creeks and Corners’.

00:1:09:0000:01:47:00 we sight a small steam train.

00:02:10:00 a rail bridge.

00:02:38:00 travellers arrive at the township of Quorn (South Australia)

00:03:01:00 the Quorn train station; long transport steam trains. sign for the township of Marree.

00:04:15:00 footage includes looking at the wheels and tracks, passengers awaiting trains, local Indigenous people, scenes of the outback taken from the train.

00:06:10:00 the traintrip reaches the township of Beresford and then the William Creek Hotel at 00:06:40:00 where we see passengers having fetched bottles of beer from the hotel sprinting back to the train.

00:06:50:00 a glimpse of (probably) brumbies and more scenes of locals and the surrounding countryside from travelling train.

00:09:27:00 we sight traindrivers or workers walking alongside the train, travel by a sheep station and through a very arid landscape.

00:10:20:00 the sign for Alice Springs comes into view. Kenneth starts a tour of the town with some police officers speaking to the camera and footage of families and their cars in one of the streets. Footage includes wandering around the wide dusty roads, people walking and on bicycles and then a look at the buildings - houses, a focus on an older building made (unusually of brick), eucalyptus trees and a flowering garden,

00:11:33:00 we see a sign for the ‘Australian Inland Mission Hostel for bush mothers and children’ on a building that Kenneth gives us several views of including a motorbike outside. This is followed by a view of a new and very modern looking building, surrounded by vegetable or market gardens and out front of which Mrs Rankine chats with acquaintances who point her up to a monument on a hill.

00:12:10:00 is a view from the monument, overlooking the town including views of its oval and what appears to be a prison.

00:13:19:00 view of eucalypts in the surrounding landscape.

00:13:40:00 we see a marker for ‘Flynn’s Grave’ which is a beautiful boulder perched on a stone pedestal.

00:14:04:00 a sign for ‘Standley Chasm’ appears and begins a sequence of dramatic and beautiful scenes of rocky outcrops, foliage and trees. Kenneth films some walkers among the rocks which shows the size and context of the environment.

00:15:31:00 we see two Indigenous horsemen followed by a sign for ‘Hermannsberg’ and some shots of the mission church building, some members of the community and a group of children smiling for the camera. The reel ends with some last looks at the landscape.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 31]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film begins with the title ‘Beauty in Victoria’ which is Kenneth’s reference to the beauty that includes nature, the Queen, a ‘bathing beauty’ contest and city night lights. Titles for the reel also include ‘Visit the Buchan Caves’ with specific directions to a ‘Modern Camp Site’ both of which introduce a lengthy look at the Buchan area. The reel ends with a quick look at ‘Port Campbell’.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:28:00 on the way to the caves, the Rankines make a stop at the Caves Hotel where Mrs Rankine keeps an eye on a magpie alongside the family car which as always, features in Kenneth’s travel footage.

00:00:39:00 the camp site is within the ‘Buchan Caves National Park’ whcih is well signed on an overhead stone archway.

00:00:49:00 begins a sequence of shots that show off the ‘modern’ camp site. We see the ‘A E LIND’ Swimming Pool, the various amenities and stone and timber buildings of the camp area such as the ‘Children’s Playground’, ‘Kitchen’ and ‘Carwash’. We also see a wonderful red truck of the era and plenty of wandering sheep.

00:01:55:00 we see Mrs Rankine at the ‘Royal Cave’ entrance.

00:02:26:00 a sequence of farmland views and shots of a bluetongue lizard.

00:03:27:00 title ‘Coronation Week’ begins with a picture of the Queen followed by various buildings decorated in British colours of red, white and blue.

00:03:58:00 decorated Palais theatre and Luna Park at St Kilda.

00:04:41:00 Melbourne city streets and department stores such as a highly decorated Myer and Foy’s departments stores, and the Queen’s name across the Elizabeth St entrance to the Flinders St Station.

00:05:30:00 Kenneth begins a nightlights sequence to show the decorations in neon.

00:09:33:00 ‘The Sun Beach Girl Finals’ where Kenneth films the parade and judges without filming the winner but showing the popularity of these events.

00:14:04:00 title ‘Port Campbell’ and brief views of the windy, rocky coastline and dramatic waves.
